abstract.p: Background: Nursing home care increasingly targets those elderly with the greatest needs in terms of personal daily activities, whereas services supporting spiritual needs such as hope tend to be ignored. Hope is seen to be a dynamic life force vital to well-being. Nursing home patients are frail, vulnerable, and dependent, which may lead to their hope being intimately related to the nurse–patient interaction. Purpose: The purpose of this study was to investigate the relationship between nurse–patient interaction and hope among cognitively intact nursing home patients. Design and method: Cross-sectional data were obtained by means of one-on-one interviews; 202 cognitively intact nursinghome patients representing 44 Norwegian nursing homes responded to the Herth Hope Index and the Nurse–Patient Interaction Scale. The hypothesized relationships between a two-factor construct of hope and nurse–patient interaction were assessed by means of structural equation modelling. Results: The structural equation model revealed a good fit to the data, showing significant influence of nurse–patient interaction on nursing home patients’ level of hope. Conclusion and implications: Nurse–patient interaction significantly influences hope in cognitively intact nursing home patients. Offering connectedness should be a central and integral aspect of holistic nursing home care. Providing continuing educational programs for caregivers focusing on how to interact with patients in a health-promoting and hopeful manner seems essential.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The life expectancy of the population is increasing worldwide. The most rapidly growing segment is people older than 80 years (Kinsella & He, 2009). For many of those 80 years and older, issues such as physical illness and approaching mortality decimate their functioning and subsequently lead to the need for nursing home (NH) care. NH care increasingly targets those elderly with the greatest needs in terms of personal daily activities, whereas services supporting spiritual needs such as hope and meaning in life tend to be ignored (Haugan Hovdenes, 2002; Vaarama & Tiit, 2007). The NH life is institutionalized, representing loss of social relationships, privacy, self-determination, and connectedness; quality of life (QoL) is often thought to be strongly compromised (Baltes & Smith, 2003). Significantly higher levels of hopelessness, helplessness, and depression are found among patients in NHs compared to those living in the community (Jongenelis et al., 2003; Ron, 2004). Nurturing body, mind, and spirit is part of holistic care, and yet often the primary focus of NH care is physical needs (Slettebø et al., 2010).

The hope dimension has for long been a central nursing concept and has been largely described in nursing theories (Kylmä & Vehviläinen-Julkunen, 1997; Miller, 2007; Tutton, Seers, & Langstaff, 2009). An oft-quoted definition of hope by nurses is hope seen as a multidimensional dynamic life force characterized by a confident, yet uncertain expectation of achieving something good, which is realistically possible and personally significant (Dufault & Martocchio, 1985). Tutton et al. (2009) examined the nature of hope in nursing literature, identifying several nursing frameworks linking hope with suffering, enduring, and uncertainty (Morse & Penrod, 1999; Travelbee, 1979). Travelbee’s model of nursing care emphasized that helping patients experience hope and avoid hopelessness is a fundamental part of nursing practice. According to Travelbee, hope is facilitated through interpersonal relationships with nursing staff. Thus, an understanding of hope and its meaning in the lives of institutionalized elders may aid in developing interventions to enhance hope and well-being in this setting.

Hope is needed by all persons throughout the life cycle and through illness and losses, including the end of life (Miller, 2007). The experience of hope has been described in different patient groups, although studies exploring hope in a long-term NH population are scarce; most existing work has been done with chronically ill, stroke, cancer, and palliative patients (Akechi et al., 2012; Alidina & Tettero, 2010; Bright, Kayes, McCann, & McPherson, 2011; Duggleby et al., 2012; Ellefsen, 2012).

However, as populations are getting older and thus live with several chronic illnesses affecting their everyday lives, it is relevant to broaden the definition of palliative care to include patient groups other than cancer patients (Franklin, Ternestedt, & Nordenfelt, 2006). NH patients are not getting healthier; they suffer from several chronic illnesses and losses, and are facing death. Therefore, the literature describing hope in palliative patients might enlighten the hope facets among NH patients. The focus of hope in palliative patients is different from that in other patient populations; chronically ill patients (Duggleby et al., 2010), trauma patients (Tutton, Seers, & Langstaff, 2012), stroke patients (Satink et al., 2013), later adulthood patients (Ong, Edwards, & Bergeman, 2006), and patients with chronic pain (Wright et al., 2011) focus their hope on getting better and living longer. However, this might not be the main hope for long-term NH patients.

Studies among palliative patients demonstrate hope to be an inner resource (Alidina & Tettero, 2010; Bright et al., 2011; Buckley & Herth, 2004) and a coping mechanism essential for QoL (Farone, Fitzpatrick, & Bushfield, 2008; Smedema, Catalano, & Ebener, 2010). Older palliative patients described their main concern as wanting “to live with hope” and achieved this through acknowledging “life the way it is,” searching for meaning, and positive reappraisal (Duggleby et al., 2007; Olsson, Östlund, Grassman, Friedrichsen, & Strang, 2010). Positive self-worth and humor have been found to be positively associated with hope and subjective well-being (Hong & Ow, 2008; Smedema et al., 2010).

Hope is the act by which despair is actively overcome. As an inner strength, hope is perceived as a resource for living in the present and is central to a dignified end of lifetime and death among NH patients (Bright et al., 2011; Franklin et al., 2006). Furthermore, inner strength among older individuals has been associated with connectedness, firmness, flexibility, creativity, a sense of confidence in oneself yet having faith in others, accepting both the light and the dark side of life, and being the same yet growing into a new garment (Holtslander & Duggleby, 2009; Lundman et al., 2010; Nygren, Norberg, & Lundman, 2007).

The Herth Hope Index (HHI) has been used in different populations, showing HHI mean score = 36.5 in a general Norwegian population (Wahl, Lerdal, & Knudsen, 2004) and 34.5 in ill adults (Herth, 1992). Recent studies have reported the level of hope between 34.0 and 41.5 for cystic fibrosis patients (Rustøen, Wahl, Hanestad, Gjengedal, & Moum, 2004), palliative patients and family members (Benzein & Berg, 2005; Guy, Higginson, & Amesbury, 2011), and cancer patients with different comorbidities (Milone, 2010; Phillips-Salimi, Haase, Kintner, Monahan, & Azzouz, 2007; Rustøen, Cooper, & Miaskowski, 2010; Schjolberg, Dodd, Henriksen, & Rustøen, 2011; Wnuk, Marcinkowski, & Fobair, 2012). Although several studies have used the HHI in different patient populations, only two studies were found including older long-term patients; a sample of 60 old adults recruited from two long-term care facilities and community-dwelling senior citizens reported hope mean score of 38 (Herth, 1993), whereas Touhy (2001) reported a hope mean score of 35.8 in an American NH sample 70 to 102 years old. Studying hope in NH patients may provide valuable evidence and a widening understanding of hope in this particular clinical setting.

Nursing is a relational process and practice; good nursing involves a process that is developmental, progressive, and sustaining, through which hope, meaning, healing, and well-being occur (Reed, 2009; Travelbee, 1979; Watson, 2007). Most NH patients have few relationships left that provide dialogue, self-reflection, and connectedness, and the social climate in a NH environment is largely determined by the staff–patient interactions that take place within it (Cahill, Doran, & Watson, 2012; Haugan, Innstrand, & Moksnes, in press; Nakrem, Vinsnes, & Seim, 2011). Patients who are listened to feel good, satisfied, and cared about; if NH patients experience not being attended to or being treated with indifference, then these patients face meaninglessness and suffering (Finch, 2005, 2006; Haugan Hovdenes, 2002). Nurse–patient interaction has been seen to be essential to patients’ sense of trust, comfort, and safety and is found to enhance meaning (Haugan, in press), self-transcendence (Haugan, Hanssen, Rannestad, & Espnes, 2012), and multidimensional well-being (Haugan, Espnes, Rannestad, Hammervold, & Garåsen, 2011; Haugan, Hanssen, & Moksnes, 2012), as well as preventing and decreasing anxiety and depression (Haugan, Innstrand, et al., in press). NH patients are frail, vulnerable, and dependent; thus, we hypothesized that the nurse–patient interaction would affect NH patients’ level of hope.

sec.title: Aims and Hypotheses
sec.p: This study investigated the relationship between hope and nurse–patient interaction among cognitively intact NH patients by means of structural equation modelling (SEM). A recently documented two-factor construct of the HHI among NH patients (Haugan, Utvær, & Moksnes, in press) was applied, comprising the factors Hope-1 (sense of positive readiness, expectancy, and temporality) and Hope-2 (having a deep inner strength, the ability of giving/receiving love/care, and the ability of recalling positive experiences). Based on the theoretical and empirical knowledge, the research question was the following: Does the nurse–patient interaction affect hope in cognitively intact NH patients? The following hypotheses were formulated:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1 (H1): Nurse–patient interaction positively affects Hope-1.
Hypothesis 2 (H2): Nurse–patient interaction positively affects Hope-2.

sec.p: Hope-2 involves features more seen as personality traits than the aspects included in Hope-1. Thus, the third hypothesis was based on a rationale that Hope-2 would positively relate to Hope-1.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: Inclusion criteria were as follows: (a) local authority’s decision of long-term NH care, (b) informed consent competency recognized by responsible doctor and nurse, and (c) capable of being interviewed. Long-term NH care was defined as 24-hour care for 6 months or longer; short-term care patients, rehabilitations patients, and cognitively impaired patients were not included. Missing data were low in frequency, hope 4.5% and nurse–patient interaction 4.0%, and were handled by means of the listwise procedure.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: A cross-sectional design was employed, and data collection was carried out during 2008 and 2009 in Mid-Norway. Approval by the Norwegian Social Science Data Services was obtained for a license to maintain a register containing personal data (Ref. No. 16443), and likewise we attained approval from The Regional Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics in Central Norway (Ref No. 4.2007.645) as well as the Management Units at the 44 NHs. The NH patients were approached by a head nurse they knew well. The nurse presented them with oral and written information about their rights as participants and their rights to withdraw at any time. Each participant provided informed consent. Because this population has problems completing a questionnaire independently, three trained researchers conducted one-on-one interviews in private. Researchers with identical professional background were selected (MA, registered nurse, and experienced in communication with elderly, as well as teaching gerontology at an advanced level) and trained to conduct the interviews as identically as possible. Interrater reliability was assessed by comparing mean scores between interviewers by means of Bonferroni-corrected one-way analyses of variance. No statistically significant differences were found that were not accounted for by known differences between the areas in which the interviewers operated. The questionnaires used were part of a questionnaire comprising 130 items; thus small breaks on specific points during the interview process were adopted to avoid tiring the participants. The interviews lasted for 1 to 2.5 hours. The interviewers held a large-print copy of questions and possible responses in front of the participants in an effort to avoid misunderstandings.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Hope was assessed by the HHI, comprising 12 items using a 4-point Likert-type response format (from strongly disagree to strongly agree). Possible scores ranged from 12 to 48, with higher scores indicating greater hopefulness (Appendix 1, see jhn.sagepub.com/supplemental). Cronbach’s alpha in the present study was .76. Several psychometrically sound measures for measuring hope among adults have been developed. The HHI was chosen for the present study because it is based on a universal concept of hope and designed for clinical settings such as older people care and cancer patients (Herth, 1992). Furthermore, the HHI is brief, has been translated into Norwegian, and has been tested in the general Norwegian population (Wahl et al., 2004). Moreover, the HHI is psychometrically evaluated in different samples showing acceptable internal consistency with alphas between .78 and .97, but the factor structure appears to be unstable (Benzein & Berg, 2003; Herth, 1992; Phillips-Salimi et al., 2007; Van Gestel-Timmermans, Van Den Bogaard, Brouwers, Herth, & Van Nieuwenhuizen, 2010; Wahl et al., 2004). A recent evaluation of the validity, reliability, and the factor structure of the HHI among NH patients revealed a two-factor construct comprising 11 items (dismissing Item 6) showing the best fit to the observed data (Haugan, Utvær, et al., in press). This two-factor solution including Hope-1 (Temporality and Expectancy) and Hope-2 (Interconnectedness; Haugan, Utvær, et al., in press) is applied in the SEM analysis.

Nurse–patient interaction was assessed by the Nurse–Patient Interaction Scale (NPIS), which was developed to identify important characteristics of NH patients’ experiences of nurse–patient interaction (Haugan, Hanssen, Rannestad, et al., 2012). The NPIS comprises 14 items measured on a 10-point scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 10 (very much); higher numbers indicate better nurse–patient interaction (Appendix 2, see jhn.sagepub.com/supplemental). The items were developed to measure the NH patients’ ability to derive a sense of subjective well-being through the nurse–patient interaction (Finch, 2006; Haugan Hovdenes, 2002; Hollinger-Samson & Pearson, 2000). The NPIS has shown good psychometric properties with good content validity and reliability among NH patients (Haugan, Hanssen, Rannestad, et al., 2012). Cronbach’s alpha (α =.92) and composite reliability (ρ = .82) were good.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: A SEM model of the hypothesized relations between the latent constructs of hope and nurse–patient interaction was tested by means of LISREL 8.8 (Jøreskog & Sørbom, 1995). Using SEM accounts for random measurement errors and ensures that the psychometric properties of the scales involved are more accurately derived. Since the standard errors are estimated under nonnormality, the Satorra–Bentler–scaled chi-square statistic was applied as a goodness-of-fit statistic, which is the correct asymptotic mean even under nonnormality (Jøreskog, Sørbom, du Toit, & du Toit, 2000). In line with the rule of thumb of conventional cutoff criteria (Schermelleh-Engel, Moosbrugger, & Muller, 2003), the following fit indices were used to evaluate model fit: chi-square (a small chi-square and a nonsignificant p value correspond to good fit; Jøreskog & Sørbom, 1995) and the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) and the standardized root mean square residual (SRMR; with values below .05 indicating a good fit and values smaller than .08 interpreted as acceptable; Hu & Bentler, 1998; Schermelleh-Engel et al., 2003). Also, we used the comparative fit index (CFI) and the nonnormed fit index (NNFI) with an acceptable fit at .95 and a good fit at .97 and above, and the normed fit index (NFI) and the goodness-of-fit index (GFI) with an acceptable fit at .90 and a good fit at .95. For the adjusted GFI (AGFI), an acceptable fit was set to .85 and a good fit at .90 (Hu & Bentler, 1998; Schermelleh-Engel et al., 2003).

Before examining the hypothesized relationships, the measurement models were tested by confirmatory factor analysis (CFA). Some hope items loaded very low, showing extremely low R2 values; these items (HHI2 λ = .26 and R2 = .12, HHI3 λ = .25, R2 = .10) were excluded. The CFA provided a good fit to the observed data for the two-factor construct of hope (χ2 = 33.61, degrees of freedom [df] = 26, p < .027; RMSEA = .039, p < .65, SRMR = .052, NFI = .94, NNFI/CFI = .98/.99, GFI/AGFI = .95/.92). A sufficient power analysis is dependent on the ratio between the total number of variables and the sample size; one observed variable per 10 patients is given as a rule of thumb (Hair, Black, Babin, & Anderson, 2010; Kline, 2005; Schumacker & Lomax, 2004). Thus, to reduce model complexity, the measure model for nurse–patient interaction was tested by CFA, reducing the indicator variables to nine (χ2 = 33.16, df = 27, p < .19; RMSEA = .035, p < .72, SRMR = .037, NFI = .98, NNFI = 1.00, CFI = 1.00, GFI = .94, AGFI = .90).

sec.title: Descriptive Analysis
sec.p: The total sample comprised 202 (80.8%) of 250 long-term NH patients representing 44 Norwegian NHs. The sample characteristics are listed in Table 1. In the SEM analysis, missing data were handled by means of the listwise procedure, resulting in an effective sample N = 189. In this study the global HHI mean score was 35.14 (SD = 4.178), which is close to previous results among NH patients with hope mean score = 35.8 (Touhy, 2001), and inside the range of previous studies reporting means of 34 to 41.

sec.p: All factor loadings were significant (p < .05) and loaded positively and clearly on their intended latent variable, with standardized factor loadings between .47 and .82 and R2 values of .22 to .67. For scaling, the variance of the dependent latent variable was set at 1. The estimated model fit well with the data (χ2 = 156.22, df = 132, p < .074, χ2/df = 1.18, RMSEA = .031, SRMR = .053, NFI = .94, NNFI/CFI = .99/.99, GFI/AGFI = .90/.87). Composite reliability was good; .76 for Hope-1, .66 for Hope-2, and .92 for nurse–patient interaction, supporting the model (Table 3); values ≥.6 are desirable and values >.7 are good (Diamantopolous & Siguaw, 2008; Hair et al., 2010).

Table 3 shows the standardized regression coefficients of the directional relationships and the total effects between the latent constructs. The directional path from nurse–patient interaction to Hope-1 (H1) displayed a significant positive association (γ1,1 = .25*). However, the path from NPIS to Hope-2 (H2) was not significant (γ2,1 = .10), whereas the path from Hope-2 to Hope-1 (H3) was significant (β1,2 = .52*). A scrutiny of the effects revealed statistically significant total effects from nurse–patient interaction to Hope-1. No indirect effects were displayed. Since a strong relationship between the two hope factors was displayed, we also tested the model comprising a one-dimensional construct of hope; however, this model did not fit as well with the data, with too low values for the GFI/AGFI (χ2 = 198.12, df = 134, p < .0027, χ2/df = 1.45, RMSEA = .050, SRMR = .065, NFI = .93, NNFI/CFI = .97/.98, GFI/AGFI = .87/.84).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study contributes to a holistic nursing perspective of promoting hope and thereby well-being in NH patients in three ways: (a) this study expands previous research by providing new insights to the associations between hope and nurse–patient interaction in a cognitively intact NH population; (b) empirical knowledge to the growing body of nurse–patient interaction knowledge is supplied by exploring nurse–patient interaction in long-term NH care, and nurse–patient interaction appears to be a potentially resource for hope and thus well-being in cognitively intact NH patients; (c) by means of SEM, the results from this study suggest a guideline for clinical nursing strategies promoting hope in NH patients.

The results showed a global HHI mean score (35.14) at the same level as previously reported among NH patients (35.80), and inside the range of hope mean scores in other populations. More specifically, two of the three hypotheses (H1 and H3) were supported. Interestingly, H2 testing the association between nurse–patient interaction and the Hope-2 factor (Interconnectedness) was not significant. Hope-2 includes the ability to recall happy and joyful times, the ability to give and receive love, and the sense of having a deep inner strength. Since inner strength is seen to be a vital aspect of hope (Bright et al., 2011; Franklin et al., 2006), associated with connectedness (Lundman et al., 2010; Villagomeza, 2005), this finding was unforeseen. We expected that connectedness would relate to the nurse–patient interaction. However, recent research describes hope resources among older persons with chronic illnesses to be both internal and external (Duggleby et al., 2012). Thus, our result might indicate that inner strength along with the ability of recalling happy times and giving/receiving love/care might perform more as internal personalities compared to the other hope aspects, being more receptive to outer influences. These internal hope facets appeared to be more resilient for external impacts such as the nurse–patient interaction. However, Hope-2 (Interconnectedness) was significantly associated with Hope-1 (Temporality and Expectancy), indicating these internal attributes of hope (Hope-2) to be of significance for the sense of positivity, readiness, and positive future expectations (Hope-1). Accordingly, H3 was supported, indicating that a sense of inner strength and giving/receiving love/care were bolstering patients’ positive expectations, believes, and aspirations (Hope-1).

NH patients’ positive outlook toward life, expecting each day to have a potential, and thus feeling one’s life valuable (Hope-1) were significantly related to the nurse–patient interaction; hence, H1 was supported. In line with previous research demonstrating a sense of positive self-worth to be positively associated with hope and well-being (Smedema et al., 2010; Tsai, Wong, Tsai, & Ku, 2008), NH patients’ positive readiness, expectancy, and temporality were promoted if they experienced respectful treatment and were taken seriously. Dignity in patients’ relationships with caregivers has been seen as a main well-being domain in NH patients (Burack, Weiner, Reinhardt, & Annunziato, 2012; Medvene & Lann-Wolcott, 2010). Consequently, intentionally fostering a sense of dignity by means of high-quality nurse–patient interaction might promote hope among NH patients. In this study, hope was encouraged by being carefully listened to and by the experience of caregivers’ genuine concern about the NH patient’s inner thoughts and feelings; which is in accordance with previous research (Haugan Hovdenes, 2002; Finch, 2006).

Nevertheless, due to the cross-sectional design, this study cannot make conclusions on the causality. Thus, the direction of the paths in the SEM model cannot be defined with certainty. Patients experiencing a vital inner strength (Hope-2) and having a positive outlook toward life (Hope-1) might be more self-confident and more open for dialogue and sharing their inner thoughts and feelings, and therefore more satisfied with the nurse–patient interaction.

Moving to an NH results from facing disabilities, illnesses, and mortality; thus, it might prove difficult to gain a sense of hope, a positive life outlook, as well as positive expectations in one’s daily life. Our results indicate that caregivers offering connectedness, full acceptance, support, and empowerment of the patients’ inner thoughts, feelings, and concerns positively will influence NH patients’ hope. In spite of disabilities and illnesses, NH patients’ hope can be supported by means of caregivers’ positive reappraisal empowering patients’ sense of worthiness (Duggleby et al., 2012). Advanced nurse-patient interaction requires caregivers to be more deeply involved in their patients’ experiences and provide stimulation of reflections and connections to patients’ inner thoughts and emotions.

In addition, the potential interconnection among body–mind–spirit (Guzzetta, 2005; Pederson & Emmers-Sommer, 2011) gives a new meaning to care, nurse–patient interaction, and this fascinating human quality of hope. Because long-term NH patients are frail and suffer from several illnesses and disabilities that are not going to be treated and restored, the body–mind–spirit interconnection inspires nurses while providing caring opportunities for hope and thus well-being. By fostering patients’ hope, nurses might influence not only mental and spiritual well-being but physical well-being as well.

sec.title: Implications for Clinical Nursing
sec.p: The present study revealed that being subjected to high-quality nurse–patient interaction represents a potential resource for patients’ hope. Exellence in the caregivers’ interaction with their patients appeared to substantially inspire hope in cognitively intact NH patients. Hope has been seen to be facilitated by means of transcendence and positive reappraisal (Duggleby et al., 2012), as well as external resources such as connectedness, communicating, and being affirmed and vitalized (Bright et al., 2011; Duggleby et al., 2007). Therefore, offering connectedness should be a central and integral aspect of NH care; NH caregivers should be given more time for interacting with their patients. Professional nursing care is determined by the way professional caregivers are using their knowledge, attitudes, behaviour, and communication skills to appreciate the uniqueness of the person being cared for (Warelow, Edward, & Vinek, 2008). By means of listening to the patients, communicating and treating the patients with respect, using emphatic understanding, and acknowledging him or her as a person who is to be taken seriously and attended to, caregivers will promote hope and thereby inner strength, coping, and well-being, as well as help NH patients to preserve dignity, identity, and integrity (Burack et al., 2012; Coughlan & Ward, 2007).

Finding ways to advance NH caregivers’ interactive skills and to increase caregivers’ awareness of the significance of their nurse–patient interaction seems imperative. Providing continuing educational programs for NH caregivers (Williams, 2006), focusing on how to interact with patients in a health promoting and hopeful manner, is essential. NH staffs should be given opportunities to participate in practical training communicating programs involving topics such as authentic presence, nonjudgmental recognition, active listening, and conscious choices of communicative actions, along with supervision from trained nurses as well as theoretical perspectives on hope, vulnerability, nurse–patient interaction, self-worth, and dignity. Helping staff nurses understand their value and importance as caregivers might generate value and meaning in the caregivers’ daily work. Advancing the caregivers’ presence with the patient might contribute to increased hope, meaning, and worthiness for the NH patients as well as for the staffs.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations of This Study
sec.p: This study expands previous research by testing the associations between a two-factor construct of hope and nurse–patient interaction in a cognitively intact NH population. The estimated SEM model testing associations that have not been tested previously fit well with the data and showed good factor loadings and mainly good R2 values and composite reliability, indicating good validity and reliability. Nevertheless, some limitations should be noted. The fact that the researchers visited the participants to help fill in the questionnaires might have introduced some biases into the respondents’ reporting. The questionnaires used were parts of a larger questionnaire comprising 130 items. Thus, frail, older NH patients might tire when completing the questionnaires, representing a possible bias to their reporting. To avoid such bias, experienced researchers were carefully selected and trained in conducting the interviews following a standardized procedure, including small breaks at specific points during the process. A second limitation concerns the use of self-reported data, which implies a certain risk that the findings are based on common-method variance (Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Lee, & Podsakoff, 2003).

Utilizing listwise deletion, effective sample size in this study was N = 189, which is considered a “medium-” to large-sized sample (Hair et al., 2010; Kline, 2005; Schumacker & Lomax, 2004). Considering the model complexity, a rule of thumb is one variable per 10 subjects (Hair et al., 2010; Kline, 2005; Schumacker & Lomax, 2004). The SEM model tested comprised 18 variables; consequently, a sample size of N = 189 should be sufficient. Nonetheless, a larger sample would significantly increase the statistical power of the tests. Finally, the cross-sectional design does not allow us to determine a conclusion regarding causality. A longitudinal design would have strengthened the study by allowing changes to be assessed and compared over time. Conversely, good fit does not mean that some alternative model might not fit better or be more accurate. However, nomological validity (Hair et al., 2010) representing theoretical plausibility was good; all paths corresponded well to the theoretical basis, which support the findings. Also, the model revealed good factor loadings, acceptable composite reliability, and a good fit to the data, all of which underpin the results.

sec.title: Conclusion and Further Research
sec.p: The present study concludes that nurse–patient interaction significantly influences hope in cognitively intact NH patients. Accordingly, the caring qualities encompassed in the nurse–patient interaction might influence patients’ hope, and thereby affect patients’s well-being, positively or negatively. Therefore, improving caregivers’ interaction skills and competence might lead to a strengthened hope and thus better QoL among NH patients. Further research should continue to seek insight into how NH staff can further improve their communication and interactive skills, as part of the efforts to facilitate patients’ hope, inner strength, coping, and thereby subjective well-being. Intervention studies measuring the effect of communication training programs might be useful in this manner.

bio.p: Gørill Haugan, PhD, RN, is Associate Professor, Sør-Trøndelag University College, Faculty of Nursing, Research Centre for Health Promotion and Resources, HIST. Her research program focuses on how nursing home patients’ spirituality might be focused as a resource contributing to inner strength, coping, global well-being, and quality of life.

Unni Karin Moksnes, Phd, RN, is Associate Professor, Sør-Trøndelag University College, Faculty of Nursing, Research Centre for Health Promotion and Resources, HIST. Her research program focuses on stress and health promotion in the youth.

Geir Arild Espnes, PhD, MPsych, RN, is Professor, Norwegian University of Science and Technology and Sør-Trøndelag University College, and Director of the Research Centre for Health Promotion and Resources, Norwegian University of Science and Technology. He is widely published in health psychology and health promotion literature.
